title: WINTER RECORDS OF BATS IN OREGON AND WASHINGTON
abstract: Hawks 1972). The Baker county record (Table 1) is the first distributional record from northeastern Oregon. Myotis volans was the only species seen hibernating in a cluster. Two such clusters occurred at the Lower QM Cave site. T. brasiliensis is found in southwestern Oregon throughout the year. S. Cross (pers. comm.) noted fresh guano on a daily basis below a winter roost in Ashland, Oregon, suggesting foraging activity throughout the winter. All species noted except M. thysanodes are encountered regularly during summer throughout their ranges in Oregon. Known winter populations are a small fraction of summer populations. Our results seem to indicate northwest hibernacula for bats differ from those of midwestern and eastern US hibernacula in that: few individuals are present at each site; species commonly encountered in hibernacula of the eastern USA (e.g. M. Iucifugus, E. fuscus) are rare or absent; and buildings are used by some bat species in place of caves or mines, particularly west of the Cascade Mountains where winter weather is milder.

abstract.text: Hawks 1972). The Baker county record (Table 1) is the first distributional record from northeastern Oregon. Myotis volans was the only species seen hibernating in a cluster. Two such clusters occurred at the Lower QM Cave site. T. brasiliensis is found in southwestern Oregon throughout the year. S. Cross (pers. comm.) noted fresh guano on a daily basis below a winter roost in Ashland, Oregon, suggesting foraging activity throughout the winter. All species noted except M. thysanodes are encountered regularly during summer throughout their ranges in Oregon. Known winter populations are a small fraction of summer populations. Our results seem to indicate northwest hibernacula for bats differ from those of midwestern and eastern US hibernacula in that: few individuals are present at each site; species commonly encountered in hibernacula of the eastern USA (e.g. M. Iucifugus, E. fuscus) are rare or absent; and buildings are used by some bat species in place of caves or mines, particularly west of the Cascade Mountains where winter weather is milder.

body_text.text: Of the 15 bat species other than Plecotus townsendii in Oregon and Washington, at least two are considered migratory. Five species (Eptesicus fuscus, Myotis californicus, M. Iucifugus, M. volans, Antrozous pallidus) are known to hibernate in the eastern portion of their ranges (Barbour and Davis 1969; Twente 1960) . Marcot (1984) reported records for hibernating Myotis evotis in northern California, Senger et al. (1974) noted five species of hibernating myotids (M. californicus, M. evotis, M.
Iucifugus, M. volans and M. yumanensis) in Washington, Genter (1986) observed hibernating M. Ie.;bii in Idaho, and Jewett (1955) recorded Tadarida brasiliensis from buildings in southwestern Oregon.

Most hibernacula contained relatively few bats (range = 1-41) when compared with those of the eastern United States (Barbour and Davis 1969) . The reports were from studies concentrated in small geographical areas and involved a small number of caves. Twente (1960) , who investigated over 600 potential hibernacula in Utah, speculated few hibernating bats were noted because of warm temperatures in the caves. Genter (1986) , Marcot (1984) , and Senger et al. (1974) suggest that hibernacula in the Pacific Northwest may contain larger bat populations than reported by Twente (1960) . This prompted us to conduct a more extensive search that included most of Oregon and Washington.

We defined winter as the period from 1 November to 1 April. During winters of 1982-1989, we searched more than 650 caves and mines and 70 buildings in Oregon and Washington. Seven of the caves were previously surveyed by Senger et al. (1974) . Most bats were easily identified from observable external characters (Hall 1981) . Closely related species (M. Iucifugus, M. yomRnensis; and M. thysanodes, M. evotis) were collected if positive identification could not be made in the field.

In addition, we obtained winter records of museum specimens collected in Oregon and Washington from American Museum of Natural History (AMNH), the National Museum (USNM), the University of Puget Sound (PSMNH), the University of Washington (UW), Southern Oregon State College (SOSC), the San Diego Museum of Natural History (SDMNH), Oregon State University (OSUFW), the University of Michigan (UMMZ), and Walla Walla College (WWC).

We located 174 bats of seven species at 26 sites (Table 1) . M. volans (124) and M. Ieibii (36) were encountered more than any other species. Numbers of bats were <10 except at two locales (one sampled twice). We noted 74 museum specimens comprising 10 species that were collected during winter (Table 2) .

Most wintering E. tuscus were found in buildings (16 of 17). These specimens are apparently the first published winter records for Oregon and Washington. Absence from caves during hibernation periods is more consistent with eastern subspecies than midwestern ones (Barbour and Davis 1969; Martin et al. 1966; Phillips 1966) . The Tacoma, Washington, record for L. noctivagans was noted previously by Johnson (1953) and Izor (1979) . Most M. californicus records are from buildings (19 of 27). Barbour and Davis (1969) Results of Genter (1986) , Marcot (1984) , and Senger et al. (1974) suggest that hibernacula in the Pacific Northwest may contain larger bat populations than reported by Twente (1960) . This prompted us to conduct a more extensive search that included most of Oregon and Washington.

We defined winter as the period from 1 November to 1 April. During winters of 1982-1989, we searched more than 650 caves and mines and 70 buildings in Oregon and Washington. Seven of the caves were previously surveyed by Senger et al. (1974) . Most bats were easily identified from observable external characters (Hall 1981) We located 174 bats of seven species at 26 sites (Table 1) . M. volans (124) and M. Ieibii (36) were encountered more than any other species. Numbers of bats were <10 except at two locales (one sampled twice). We noted 74 museum specimens comprising 10 species that were collected during winter (Table 2) .

Most wintering E. tuscus were found in buildings (16 of 17). These specimens are apparently the first published winter records for Oregon and Washington. Absence from caves during hibernation periods is more consistent with eastern subspecies than midwestern ones (Barbour and Davis 1969; Martin et al. 1966; Phillips 1966) . The Tacoma, Washington, record for L. noctivagans was noted previously by Johnson (1953) and Izor (1979) . Most M. californicus records are from buildings (19 of 27). Barbour and Davis (1969) Fenton and Barclay 1980) was found, or mentioned in museum field notes.

M. evotis was found singly in caves and in one garage (Corvallis, Oregon). All were M. e. pacificus from west of the Cascade Mountains. M. Ieibii was found in caves or mines except for a single torpid female observed hanging in a twilight area of a stone cornice. As did Martin and Hawks (1972) and Senger et al. (1974) , we noted this species hanging singly and in areas where air movement was minimal.

Our records of hibernating M. thysanodes are apparently the second such report (Martin and This content downloaded from 35.7.39.109 on Thu, 07 Oct 2021 17:31:14 UTC All use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms All use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms

BIBREF0.title: It is possible most summer bats we encounter migrate long distances to suitable areas for over wintering. We believe this option is not used by most species, but that they hibernate in sites not readily accessible to examination by humans
BIBREF0.raw_text: It is possible most summer bats we encounter migrate long distances to suitable areas for over wintering. We believe this option is not used by most species, but that they hibernate in sites not readily accessible to examination by humans.

Received 13 October 1989, accepted 9 April 1990. NORTHWESTERN NATURALIST 71:59-62 AUTUMN 1990 WINTER RECORDS OF BATS IN OREGON AND WASHINGTON J. MARK PERKINS, JOHN M. BARSS, AND JOSHUA PETERSON Winter records of bats in the Pacific Northwest are extremely limited (Barbour and Davis 1969). Of the 15 bat species other than Plecotus townsendii in Oregon and Washington, at least two are considered migratory. Five species (Eptesicus fuscus, Myotis californicus, M. Iucifugus, M. volans, Antrozous pallidus) are known to hibernate in the eastern portion of their ranges (Barbour and Davis 1969; Twente 1960). Marcot (1984) reported records for hibernating Myotis evotis in northern California, Senger et al. (1974) noted five species of hibernating myotids (M. californicus, M. evotis, M. Iucifugus, M. volans and M. yumanensis) in Washington, Genter (1986) observed hibernating M. Ie.;bii in Idaho, and Jewett (1955) recorded Tadarida brasiliensis from buildings in southwestern Oregon.Most hibernacula contained relatively few bats (range = 1-41) when compared with those of the eastern United States(Barbour and Davis 1969). The reports were from studies concentrated in small geographical areas and involved a small number of caves.Twente (1960), who investigated over 600 potential hibernacula in Utah, speculated few hibernating bats were noted because of warm temperatures in the caves.
